Question:
Purpose of Debugger:

Hello,

I had a question about the window that pops up when you run the debugger. I assumed that the debugger would show me the error in my code, but now it seems that the window simply displays the last compiled version of my code. So now I am confused as to what the purpose of that window is.
Answer:
I believe the window that pops up when debugging just shows the output of your compiled code.

 

From what I understand, the debugger won’t necessarily tell you where the errors in your code are. When you have syntax errors (i.e., pritf(“Hello world”); instead of printf(“Hello world”);), you’ll get an error message in the terminal and can use that to fix the mistake.

However, the debugger can be used to identify the logical errors (errors in the code that is syntactically correct, but produces incorrect results). This can be done by setting breakpoints, which allow you to stop program execution at a specified point. From there you can examine the state of your program (i.e., values of variables) and can even run your code step-by-step to pinpoint the source of the error. It's useful for understanding your code and what each line does.

Question: value of pi for part 3: how do I get the value of Pi? i included <math.h> and then tried to use M_PI but it says the identifier is undefined, what should i do?
Answer:
Assuming that you are observing this in VSCode editor, you might need to change the "cStandard" property in "configurations" array in c_cpp_properties.json file to "gnu17" (or "gnu23").

The reason for this is because this setting apparently defaults to "c99", in which M_PI is indeed not defined. GNU's compiler provides a bunch of extensions to the standard C.

Question:
Last question in lab1:

Quick question, can we also adjust the code to have improved readability? Specifically referring to the way the variables are declared in four lines when there is a more readable way.

Answer:
in general unless stated otherwise in the lab handout it’s:
your code your choice :).

As long as you’re not doing something outlandish like making a C wrapper that calls a python script because you hate C or something like that then you can do whatever you please or including some library that does the entire lab (shouldn’t be possible) in one or two lines

So yes to your first question unless it says you cannot modify anything in the lab handout 

Comments are not marked, you can choose to leave them there or not but in general they’re helpful especially if you want to look back on your code and figure out what you did (we often forget)

Question:
Lab1 Part 3 ECF Remote compilation error:

Hello,

I completed lab1part3 and it passes the test cases, but it won't run when i click compile on ECF (but it does compile and run locally). 

I've attached an image of the results of my code passing the test cases and the error I get after compiling it on ECF. How can I define 'pow' and 'sqrt' on ECF?
Answer:
Make sure you include the -lm switch when invoking the gcc command on ECF machine.

In certain environments, the math library is not included during the linking process while compilation. So, you have to explicitly tell the compiler to link it by adding the -lm flag to the compilation command as the following.

gcc programName.c -lm -o programName

For more details about compilation and linking on C, please refer to this article, https://wahyu-ehs.medium.com/compiling-and-linking-on-c-programming-b22eb634d27

In certain enviroments, the math library is not included during the linking process while compilation. So, you have to explicitly tell the compiler to link it by adding the -lm flag in the compilation command. 
gcc program.c -lm -o program

Question:
Snefru 2.2 Quiz question 2:

Aren't 1,0,5 also integers? So why can't %d be used in this case?
Answer:
In this case, '1', '0', and '5' are of the character type (due to the single quotations). When we are using the integer format specifier (%d) on a character, the program will convert the character into its equivalent ASCII code. If you were to test it out, the output would be "The course number is APS494853". You can look up its equivalent code in a table such as the following (left column is ASCII code in decimal, right column is the character):

Note that this corresponds to '1' = 49, '0' = 48, '5' = 53, which is what you see printed.

Question:
Addresses and & usage:

Hello,

I just wanted some clarification on the use of &. When using scanf, you are required to specify the format specifier as well as the variable so it looks like this for example:

scanf("%d", &pizza) ;

from my understanding, & accesses the variable's address so is the users input being stored in place of the address or the address' corresponding value? 

Additionally, once we initialize a variable, why do we not use the & to define a value for it. For example why do we do 

int pizza, slice;

pizza = 8;

slice = pizza*8 ;

and not:

int pizza, slice;

&pizza = 8

&slice = pizza*8

Hopefully my questions make sense! Thank you in advance
Answer:
in the scanf function '&' operator is used to fetch the address of the variable where values entered by the user or simply the user input, should be stored. when you use '&pizza', you are directly providing the address of thre 'pizza' variable to 'scanf', so as a result the user input would be stored at the memory location of the variable 'pizza'

Answering your second question, when you initialize a variable, a value gets assigned to the variable directly. The code initializes the 'pizza' variable with the value of 8, '&' is not used in this context because you are not taking the address, instead you are assigning a value to a variable. If you use '&pizza' then it would result in a compilation error because the left side of the assignmed should be a variable and not an address, so '&pizza', is an address thats why we do not use it.

Hopefully it helps..

You will know a lot more when we talk about address in the future. That is a very big topic and could say the most important/useful/painful feature that C/C++ has but most other programming languages don't. You will know a lot more when we talk about address in the future. That is a very big topic.

Question:
Lab 1 Part 2:

When I was reading over the instructions, there is something weird about the outputs in this example. The instructions state that we have to display the difference in degrees fahrenheit, but the difference is not in degrees fahrenheit. When I calculated the difference in this example, it was 3.7 degrees celsius. In fahrenheit, that would be around 38.66 not 6.7. Is my interpretation of the instructions false or is this example incorrect?
Answer: Good question. The explanation you provided is false since this is not how you calculate the difference in Fahrenheit. Instead, first convert 22 deg C to 71.6 def F. Then, subtract 71.6 from 78.3 to yield 6.7 deg F. Therefore, the example is indeed correct.

Question: textbook1.2: why the bit on the left is "four's bit"? There are only three bits.
Answer:
It means the place value in binary for that value, not how many bits are there.

Binary goes from

1,2,4,8,16,32,64, etc

but increases from right to left so it would be 

etc, 64, 32, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1

The most significant bit (3 bits total) is equal to the value 4.

the one to the right of that would be called the two's bit and then the one's bit

It means the place value in binary for that value, not how many bits are there.

but increases from right to left so it would be

Question: textbook2.2 quiz1: why can the minimum reach to -2048? I think it should be (-1-4-8-16-32-...-1024=-2047).
Answer:
with 12 bits from that unsigned datatype you can represent $$2^{12}$$ different numbers. notice that the numbers $$0\to2047$$ represent $$2^{11}$$ numbers, and the numbers $$-2048\to-1$$ represent another $$2^{11}$$ numbers for a total of $$2^{12}$$ numbers.

the reason the positive range ends in a smaller absolute value is because something needs to represent zero. by convention they subtract this from the positive range. however there's no use in doing this for the negative range because there's no point in having a $$+0$$ and a $$-0$$. (although iirc floats do have a $$\pm0$$ for technical reasons). with 12 bits from that unsigned datatype you can represent $$2^{12}$$ different numbers. notice that the numbers $$0\to1023$$ represent $$2^{11}$$ numbers, and the numbers $$-1024\to-1$$ represent another $$2^{11}$$ numbers for a total of $$2^{12}$$ numbers.

Question: Textbook 2.3.2: How do we define "accurate" here? I think a double( fraction number )is more accurate than just store it as an integer.
Answer:
The accuracy depends on the data types of the numbers. For example, 5 / 2 = 2, since the operands (numbers) involved are both of type integer, the result will truncate (remove) any decimal result and keep the integer. However, if the operation was 5.0 / 2, the most accurate data type involved is a double, so 5.0 / 2 will output 2.5.
The accuracy depends on the data types of the numbers. For example, 5 / 2 = 2, since the operands (numbers) involved are both of type integer, the result will truncate (remove) any decimal result keep the integer. However, if the operation was 5.0 / 2, the most accurate data type involved is a double, so 5.0 / 2 will output 2.5.

Those operators are left-associative, which means if they are on the same precedence level, they are evaluated from left to right. Those operators are left-associative, which means if they are on the same precendence level, they are evaluated from left to right. as your fellow student said

Question:
textbook practice test problem:

can anyone explain why D is correct?
Answer:
n is less than or equal to 0 is false because n is greater than 0, so the result is false. Then, the result (false) is not equal to 1 (which represents true) which is a true statement, so the final statement is true
n is less than or equal to 0 is false because n is greater than 0, and then false is not equal to 1 (which represents true) which is a true statement
n is less than or equal to 0 is false because n is above 0, and then false is not equal to 1 (which represents true) which is a true statement

Question:
Where does VS studio code return 0?:

Hi, I'm having a slight trouble finding where the 0 is if the code executes successfully. Do you guys know where it is? I thought it would be in the output section of VS code but it'll only give an error. Thanks : )
Answer:
I believe this value isn't outputted in the output or terminal, as it is something that is used by the operating system to see if your program ran successfully. If no errors (syntax related) come up, that means your program has run successfully.
<md>If your question is "Where is the 0 from `return 0;`?"

It is not printed. Printed things are only printed through `printf`.

We haven't yet discussed functions, so the following information is missing. It is a value that can be used to know if your code ran successfully. 

Try out return 1 (or any non-zero) number in VS Code. It will show that your code terminated with an exit code that is the same as the number you entered. Any non-zero number will result in a message saying your code exited with non-zero exit code. This signals something went wrong. If we reached a return 0. The code will stop executing, and exit code is 0 (meaning successful execution).

![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fjlzv60dhucu1fm%2Fb8472f751fa2b39b121c5c659a9654900f63c877e17c4b9558efb44e4a93b6bb%2Fimage.png)</md>

Question: Lab 2 - Part 2: I am having a slight issue rounding the minute to the lowest minute. My approach was to convert the arrival time to a decimal, do all necessary calculations, then convert the decimal to minutes; however, when I try to typecast or floor a double that gets outputted as what seems to be a whole number, it goes to the preceding number (e.g. 12.0 --> 11). I believe this is because floats are not totally precise, which is probably the case in the issue I am having, and I know using the round function will violate the condition of rounding the minute to the lowest minute for some cases, so I am wondering what I can do to solve this issue. Any hints or suggestions will be greatly appreciated!
Answer:
If this issue is with all numbers, please post a private post with your code, and I will look into it. Or better, try using the debugger. It will show you what is stored in the numbers. 

I am afraid your issue is just with certain numbers. If this is the case, yes. `double` or `float` are not data types that store all numbers after the decimal place, so there is an issue with precision indeed. There are ways to avoid it, but it's too advanced for the course to discuss. This is one place that discusses this issue online: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/build/why-floating-point-numbers-may-lose-precision?view=msvc-170

Question:
C storing approximate values:

Hi,

C is storing the value of 4.1 * 60 as 245.99999 instead of 246 (the correct answer). This is causing issues when I try to integer cast. Has anyone experienced this?
Answer:
I have been experiencing this as well. One approach that I think can help is to store the minutes data in the integer part of a number, rather than in the fractional one. For instance, for "1 hour and 30 minutes", instead of storing it as 1.5 store it as 90.

*Seperate person here: Can you show exactly what the result is? C will sometimes have wonky ways to store the data values,  but most of the time it is reliable. 

I have been experiencing this as well. One approach that I think can help is to store the minutes data in the integer part of a number, rather than in the fractional one. For instance, for "1 hour and 30 minutes", instead of storing it as 1.5 store it as 90. I have been experiencing this as well. One approach that I think can help is to store the minutes data in the "integral" part of a number, rather than in the fractional one. For instance, for "1 hour and 30 minutes", instead of storing it as 1.5 store it as 90. I have been experiencing this as well. One approach that I think can help is to store the minutes data in the "integral" part of a number, rather than in the fractional one. For instance, for "1 hour and 30 minutes", instead of storing it as 1.5 store it as 90. This is because that double has limited precision. It is normal that there is a small delta between what you want to store and the actual value that  the machine stores. 

Check this link of IEEE 754 specification for more detail. https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19957-01/806-3568/ncg_math.html#:~:text=IEEE%20754%20specifies%3A,and%20occupies%2064%20bits%20overall.

This is because that double has limited precision. It is normal that there is a small delta between what you want to store and the actual value that  the machine stores.

Question:
lecture8 note:

What is the difference between we use 3 'if' and 'if' +  'else if' +'else'?

can we get the same result here if we use 3 'if'
Answer:
For this example, you can get the same results by using 3 if statements instead of using if + else if + else.

You can think of if + else if + else having mutually exclusive conditions (only one output will arise). Once it reaches a true condition, it will execute the corresponding code block and skip over the rest (the subsequent conditions will not be checked).

A sequence of if statements are independent of one another. Each condition is evaluated regardless if previous if statements are executed. This can have some implications, consider:

int x = 35;

if(x > 30) {

    printf("x > 30");

} else if(x > 20) {

    printf("x > 20");

} else {

    printf("x < 20");

}

The output will only be "x > 30", whereas if you use a sequence of if statements:

if(x > 30) {

    printf("x > 30");

}

if(x > 20) {

    printf("x > 20");

}

if(x > 10) {

    printf("x > 10");

}

The output of this would be:

"x > 30"

"x > 20"

"x > 10"

You can think of if + else if + else has mutually exclusive conditions (only one output will arise). Once it reaches a true condition, it will execute the corresponding code block and skip over the rest (the subsequent conditions will not be checked).

A sequence of if statements are independent of one another. Each condition is evaluated regardless if other if statements are executed. This can have some implications, consider:

int x = 35;

if(x > 30) {

    printf("x > 30");

} else if(x > 20) {

    printf("x > 20");

} else {

    printf("x < 20");

}

The output will only be "x > 30", whereas if you use a sequence of if statements:

if(x > 30) {

}

if(x > 20) {

    printf("x > 20");

}

}

"x > 30"

Question:
debugging:

If you notice an error that is not executed yet when using the debugger and go to edit it, do you need to stop/exit/restart the debugger (after compiling the edited code) in order for the debugger to run the edited code? Or can you just compile the edited code and continue stepping over on the debugger?

Basically I'm asking: if you're debugging and decide to edit and compile something in your code that is not executed yet, does the debugger run your un-edited un-compiled code? Or does it run the edited, compiled version of your code?
Answer: Always recompile. Debugger is running the executable. Compile is the process of translating your source code to the executable.

Question:
arithmetic operator issue?:

When trying to do the following arithmetic operation, the following error always occurs:

Why does result store 0?

(I've made sure to compile my code before using the debugger).

But when I change the (1/2)*(50) to 50/2, it yields the correct answer:

What am I doing wrong in the first scenario?
Answer:
It's because you are performing integer division. An integer is the most accurate data type involved in 1/2, so the quotient will be an integer. This means any decimal result will be truncated (0.5 turns into 0). To change this, you just need to make one the the operands a double (i.e. 1.0 / 2).

This section of the textbook discusses this: https://learningc.org/chapters/chapter02-variables/operations#the-more-accurate-data-type-is-contagious

It's because you are performing integer division. An integer is the most accurate data type involved in 1/2, so the quotient will be an integer. This means any decimal result will be truncated (0.5 turns into 0). To change this, you just need to make one the the operands a double (i.e. 1.0 / 2)

Question: Pointers Textbook: I was reading the textbook and came across this snippet of code. I am wondering why p is being dereferenced before p is even created. Does the order not matter?Screenshot_2024-02-04_at_2.17.56_PM.png
Answer:
A pointer is declared with the asterisk. That is not a dereference but a declaration. You don’t necessarily need to use brackets around the variable type like so (int*) p. You can directly declare a variable as is seen in the image.

Be careful of the pointer type vs. dereference operator.

int* a; <-- pointer type declaration

*a;      <-- dereference operator

&a;     <-- address of operator

Question: Pointer confusion: what’s the difference between assigning a variable to be another variable Vesurses using a pointer? Please clarify thanks
Answer:
Here's what I think:

- When we assign a variable to another variable, it only copies its value.

- When we assign a variable to a pointer, we assign its location in memory.

Therefore, when we update this pointer, we are directly changing whatever data is currently held in that location in the computer's memory.

In contrast, if we used a variable instead of a pointer, we are technically only updating the copied value that the computer has stored elsewhere, in an independent location.

Hopefully that makes sense.

The student's answer is half correct and half incorrect.

The benefit of using a pointer is to mostly save memory space.

When you pass a value to a function, the value needs to be first copied and then passed to a function. When you pass a pointer to a function, only the pointer(the address to the value you want to pass into the function) needs to be copied. If the value you want to pass into a function takes a large chunk of memory space, then the benefit of using a pointer starts to show.

The student's answer says "if we used a variable instead of a pointer, we are technically only updating the copied value that the computer has stored elsewhere, in an independent location.", this is not accurate. When you update a value, you don't need to allocate a new chunk of memory. You still update the value in-place. The only time when you need a new memory space is to copy a value. I guess the student wants to say if you want to assign one variable to another new variable, then the statement is correct. However, keep in mind that pointer is just a type of variable, it also takes memory space.

Question: Address of an VariableIs: Is the address of a variable randomly generated or does it follow any patterns?
Answer:
The address is randomly generated. If you are saying if you declare a variable on stack/heap, will the address follows some pattern then the answer is yes for some cases. Stack allocates memory from top to bottom and heap allocates memory from bottom to top.

For example, you have a code snippet like below,

int a = 0;
int b = 2;

Assume the address of a is 0xFF70 8000. Since an integer has a size of 4 bytes and b is declared on stack, b should have an address of 0xFF70 7FFC.

However, the address on heap may not be continuous if you call malloc() twice. The returned address is not guaranteed to be continuous. // <- Not sure if you have already covered malloc but you will

The address is randomly generated. If you are saying if you declare a variable on stack/heap, will the address follows some pattern then the answer is yes for some cases. Stack allocates memory from top to bottom and heap allocates memory from bottom to top.

For example, you have a code snippet like below,

int a = 0;
int b = 2;

Assume the address of a is 0xFF70 8000. Since an integer has a size of 4 bytes and b is declared on stack, b should have an address of 0xFF70 7FFC.

The address is randomly generated. If you are saying if you declare a variable on stack/heap, will the address follows some pattern then the answer is yes for some cases. Stack allocates memory from top to bottom and heap allocates memory from bottom to top. The address is randomly generated. Question: textbook 6.3: why the function can change the value of a and b? I only return the address of b in this function.
Answer:
Sorry, what do you mean by you only return the address of b?

The program starts running on line 10, creates two variables (a and b) in main. We then create a variable called f and set its value to the address of b.

On line 12: we do a function call to confuse.

confuse gets a copy of the address of a (in main) as argument x, and a copy of the address of b (in main) as the argument y and execution jumps to the confuse function.

On line 3: we dereference y, accessing the value of b (in main), and increment it. The value of b (in main) is now 8.

On line 4: we re-assign the value of y (in confuse) to the value of x. After this line the variable y now has the address of a (in main).

On line 5: we dereference y, accessing the value of a (in main), and set its value to 10. The value of a (in main) is now 10.

On line 6: we return a copy of y, which is the address of a (in main). The we're done running the confusion function, and resume in main.

On line 12: we assign f the value returned from the function. The value of f is now the address of a.

On line 13: we dereference f, accessing the value of a and increment it. The value of a is now 11.

On line 14: we print the values of a and b, currently a is 11 and b is 8.

Question:
What is an executable file:

What is an executable file for lab 4 and 5 in one of the recent announcements, and what purpose does it serve? Why is it optional and is it recommended that I run it? 

Thank you
Answer:
an executable file very simply stated is your "program" that the computer executes. It basically has some encoded sequence of instructions that the computer can understand provided by your C code. Remember how at the start of the semester, it was taught that computers only understand 0's and 1's (binary)? Well...

#include <stdio.h>

int main(void) {
		printf("Hello World\n);
}

certainly does not look like 0's and 1's but compiling it turns it into a representation your computer can understand.

A simple program like "Hello World" is actually quick complicated underneath the hood (assembly and machine instructions and what not). We are quite lucky to be coding and living in today's world, we stand on the shoulders of giants who could not just type

printf("Hello World");

and have display "Hello World". 

When you run gcc blah blah before every submission, you're generating an executable. 

Compiling a C code -> generating an executable that your computer can understand and execute.

You want to use it because the executable provided is the SOLUTION C code's program.

So you run your exectuable

You run the executable given (what is expected).

Compare the two.

I think most student's processes for doing assignments (or at least mine) goes like this:

understanding assignment instructions and program (sometimes through paper-and-pen calculations as needed) => converting into pseudo-code-like thinking for assignment approach ("assignment instructions say to do xyz repetitively, therefore I will use a for loop that repeats doing xyz until x") => writing actual code ("for (int i=0; i < example; i++){ code goes here}") => debugging for endless errors => passing test cases and chosen edge cases, and submitting

posting pseudo code might help people skip some important steps in understanding and doing the assignment themselves, by giving them an idea of what logistical structures might work to solve the problem stated in the lab instructions, and how to implement them. this is just my opinion though - I don't think pseudo code should be allowed on piazza, though I am curious to know what the instructors think. I wholeheartedly agree with the student's response! 

Sharing pseudo code does indeed solve part of the assignment and allows students to skip steps in the process of writing code. In fact, in previous years, many students shared pseudo code with one another resulting in 90%+ similar code. Cases like that constitutes as an academic integrity violation. 

You can help each other if a classmate asks about "I don't understand how do we write a loop," "I think I don't know how do I think about the condition of a loop," "I don't think I understand what part 2 in lab 5 is asking us to do," "I am getting this error and I don't know where does it come from." These are all general questions, and don't relate to the lab, and wouldn't result in having the same code. 

On a side note, as an educator, I feel happy to read the students steps to create their programs. This is exactly what we teach you to do, and seeing that you do so makes me feel proud!

Question:
2020 Midterm Question 7:

Hello! 

I just wanted to make sure I'm understanding this solution properly, since I initially mis-interpreted what the question was even asking for and now I'm a bit unsure.

So essentially what we're doing is running the while loop until we get some sort of overflow error, and then praying that the printf statement still runs after the overflow error showing us how many bits are used? If this is correct, does C normally run the rest of the code after an error or does it stop at that line and spit out the error for you to fix?

Thank you for your time!
Answer:
The purpose of the program is to determine the number of bits in an int variable (including the sign bit) without using the sizeof operator.

The solution works by creating an integer k with only one bit equal to 1, then moves it to the left (towards more significant digits) until the integer becomes negative. Since all negative integers have a bit set in the most significant position and there is only one bit set, we know that the bit has arrived at the end of the integer. We can therefore calculate the number of bits by counting the number of iterations required to do this.

It is an overflow error, but even though we use the word error to describe it, this is not an invalid operation (it's not even considered abnormal on the CPU). Thus the CPU reports no error and the program does not stop (you are right that a CPU error will stop the program however).

Question:
Midterm 2022 Question 1:

Can someone please explain how to shift the range of the rand() function? I looked at the solution and don't understand how the code works.
Answer:
Note that when using the modulo operator with positive integers, the result of num % n ranges from 0 to n - 1, as long as n is not equal to 0.

So when you do rand() % 334, the range of possible numbers is from 0 to 333. To put them in the range of 666 to 999, you can add 666 to the result.

The division by 10 then puts them in the range of 66.6 to 99.9.

Note that when taking the modulus of a positive number, the result is always is either from 0 to one less that number (num % n ranges from 0 to n - 1, as long as n is not equal to 0).

So when you do rand() % 334, the range of possible numbers is from 0 to 333. To put them in the range of 666 to 999, you can add 666 to the result.

The division by 10 then puts them in the range of 66.6 to 99.9.

Note that when taking the modulus of a number, the result is always is either from 0 to one less that number (num % n ranges from 0 to n - 1, as long as n is not equal to 0).

So when you do rand() % 334, the range of possible numbers is from 0 to 333. To put them in the range of 666 to 999, you can add 666 to the result.

The division by 10 then puts them in the range of 66.6 to 99.9.

Note that when taking the modulus of a number (when that number is not equal to 0), the result is always is either from 0 to one less that number (num % n ranges from 0 to n - 1).

So when you do rand() % 334, the range of possible numbers is from 0 to 333. To put them in the range of 666 to 999, you can add 666 to the result.

The division by 10 then puts them in the range of 66.6 to 99.9.

We will use reverse engineering. We know we can't generate real numbers (numbers with decimals using rand()), so we will generate numbers between 666 and 999 then divide by 10.0.

It's easy from here, we use the formula discussed in class. rand() generates a number between 0 and 2^31 - 1. If we do % (999 - 666 + 1), we get a number between 0 and (999 - 666). Adding to that 666, gives us a number between 666 and 999. Divide that by 10.0, and that gives you a number between 66.6 and 99.9.

Question:
modulo operator:

It appears that according to Google and Khan Academy, (-6)%18=12

because the system changes (-6)%18 to (-6)-[(-6)/18]*18

where the fraction inside the square brackets [(-6)/18] is rounded DOWN to the nearest integer.

Since -6/18 is -1/3, it rounds DOWN to -1, resulting in (-6)-(-1)(18) = 12.

However, whenever I run (-6)%18=12 or -6%18=12 in vs code, it produces -6:

 

Why does this happen??? And what is the actual answer?
Answer:
-1/3 is 0 rounded down to the nearest integer. This results in -6 - 0, which is -6.

I could be wrong here, but to my understanding there is a subtle difference between modulo and remainder that only comes into play for negative numbers. The "modulo" operator in c simply returns the remainder from division, which in the case of $$-6/18$$, is just going to be $$-6$$. That being said, this result differs from modulo (in a mathematical context) which will always give the same sign as the divisor and is defined with the equation you showed in the question

Question:
Midterm 2023 Question 4:

Hi, for question 4 of midterm 2023, how does *p have the value of myArray[5] and not 0 in another [5]? Will it be possible to explain how *p works?

Also, having p = myArray does it mean that myArray will always start at 0 and p has the index value or it has another meaning?
Answer:
I'm not exactly sure what you're asking but I can explain how pointers work with arrays and hopefully that can help.

Arrays and pointers are pretty similar in that the array identifier is a pointer to the first element of that array. In other words, when you create an array "int arr[5];", "arr" is the same thing as "&arr[0]". Thats why you can intialize a pointer "int *p;" and set them equal. "p = arr". This is the same as making p point to the first element of the array.

On the other hand, "p - arr" takes the address held in p, subtracts it from the address held in arr (&arr[0]), then divides by the size of the elements of the array (in the case of integers, it divides by 4 for the 4 bytes). It basically gives the distance between the addresses held in p and arr, so the division by 4 bytes is necessary to compensate for the fact that integers are represented with 4 bytes

Not sure how good I explained that so heres the textbook chapter for a better explanation haha 7.2. What are arrays, and how are they stored? — Snefru: Learning Programming with C (learningc.org)

I'm not exactly sure what you're asking but I can explain how pointers work with arrays and hopefully that can help.

Arrays and pointers are pretty similar in that the array identifier is a pointer to the first element of that array. In other words, when you create an array "int arr[5];", "arr" is the same thing as "&arr[0]". Thats why you can intialize a pointer "int *p;" and set them equal. "p = arr". This is the same as making p point to the first element of the array.

On the other hand, "p - arr" takes the address held in p, subtracts it from the address held in arr (&arr[0]), then divides by the size of the elements of the array (in the case of integers, it divides by 4 for the 4 bytes). It basically gives the distance between the addresses held in p and arr, so the division by 4 bytes is necessary to compensate for the fact that integers are represented with 4 bytes

`int* p` is a pointer to an integer `myArray` is a pointer to the first element in the array, i.e. `myArray` is same as `&myArray[0]` `p = myArray` means `p` has `&myArray[0]` `p++` means `p = &myArray[0] + 1` which is `&myArray[1]` In the loop, we add to p 1 every iteration, making it store the address of the next element in the array. If we dereference p using *p, then we are accessing the element in the array. For example, *p if p stored &myArray[1], then we are accessing myArray[1] which is 4. Please follow up with questions if you need further clarification.

Question:
2018 Midterm Question 6 Solution:

The question asks to provide an implementation of a function called findMaximumValue that finds the max value of an array, and if the max is negative or 0, it returns 0. In the solution however, there is no code that ensures any max values that are negative, result in 0 being returned(below). 

should the following code have to be implemented:

if (maximumValue<=0)

   return 0;

else

   return maximumValue;

or is the solution correct?
Answer: Note that <kbd>maximumValue</kbd> is initialized to 0. This means that if <kbd>list[i]</kbd> is negative, <kbd>maximumValue < list[i]</kbd> would be false, so <kbd>maximumValue</kbd> will never be set to a negative number.

Question: Question about Star patterns in C: I am struggling with creating the star patterns in C. I noticed that we always how our for loop for rows first. Then nested in the rows for loop is what. I get lost on how to think through these patterns and how to solve them effectively. What are the steps to solve these patterns effectively.
Answer:
Feel free to edit.

I understand where your struggle comes from so I'll just explain what my professor does since that breaks down your question about why there's a loop for the rows first then for the columns.

Follow these steps: 

1. Draw out the stars and spaces in a table, literally a table.

2. Label the rows and columns of the table, let me show you in this example here: 

01234
1**
2**
3**
4**

3. Identify the relationship between the rows and and columns - to do this, you need to basically see how the number for the row relates to the number for the column.

For example, the first row has a star in column 1 and 4

Second row in column 2 and 3

Third row in column 3 and 2

Fourth row in column 4 and 1 

4. Draw this out in another table to see how rows and columns relate, look at this example here:

RowColumn 1Column 2
114
223
332
441

Ah and now you see a patten :)

So you create a loop for the rows first because you see that the rows in the table increase from 1 - 4 going downward, so its logically easier, please don't memorize that, approach it with logic.

5. Okay so now we've seen a pattern which is convenient, let's just make a loop that follows those patterns in our table, which is where our logic comes into play and we code it directly, with the approach you mentioned for having a loop for the rows first and now having a loop for the columns based on what you saw on the table above.

6. So the approach is to print spaces and then print stars in the cases we identified in the table above :)

I hope that helped.

Question:
Midterm 2023 Q6:

Hi, for Question 6 of midterm 2023, I'm a bit confused why the value at a remains the same and isn't the same as b.
Answer:
Halfway through the modify function, a is changed such that it points to b. So when you run the line *a = *a + 5, it's the same thing as running *b = *b + 5. Therefore, the value at a won't be changed.

If you want a step-by-step break through of the question, Professor Eyolfson covered it in one of his midterm review lectures: https://youtu.be/iJRAmaSpj7k?t=1554

Question:
2014 Midterm Question 14:

I'm having trouble understanding the logic behind this question. If someone could explain the logic for the highlighted part it would be greatly appreciated :) Also, can we use an array of the letters (as in array[26]) and use nested loops to print elements from the array to solve the question?

piazza.jpg
Answer:
Note the pattern, as you go to 1 place to the right, you print the next character. If you go to 1 place to the bottom, you print the next character.

For example, if you go 1 place to the bottom right (diagonally), you can think as 1 place to the right and 1 place to the bottom. Therefore, you would print the next next character.

That is equivalent as saying there is some relationship between (i+j) and the character you would like to print.

The modulo operation is to make sure the character will wrap back.

Question:
array datatype and sizeof() question:

If the array identifier is a pointer to the first element of the array, then why does sizeof(arr) not return the size of the pointer?

Running this prints 20 and 8, so I'm guessing that the 20 comes from the size of the entire array (5 elements x 4 bytes per element), and the pointer to the first element of the array yields 8 as expected. To my understanding, if arr is a pointer, shouldn't it also print 8?
Answer:
Very good question. The answer is that array is weird in C. Yes, array is a pointer but not quite the same as a regular pointer. You can think of the array as an alias(or a label in a more formal terminology) to the address of the first element of the array. The array as a pointer (the address of itself) doesn't really stored anywhere in the memory space, unlike other regular pointers. Try to print the address of the array and you will find the address of the array is the address of the first element. (i.e &arr has the same value as arr)

Question:
Generating random numbers between MAX and MIN: Why is the formula to generate random numbers between max and min this:
rand()%(max-min+1) + min?
Answer:
The unmodified rand() function generates an integer between 0 and a constant (RAND_MAX) inclusive (for the sake of argument I'm assuming that RAND_MAX equals 100).

When we take the modulo $$n$$ of a number $$x$$, we calculate its residue under $$n$$ (see this article for details). In practice, this means mapping every integer to a number in the set $$\left\{0,1,\ldots,n-1\right\}$$, which has $$n$$ elements. Thus when we take rand() % n we map all of its possible outputs to a set of only $$n$$ possibilities.

The formula rand() % (max-min+1) + min is thus mapping the output of the rand() function to a set of values such that there are the same number of values as there are numbers between max and min inclusive, and then shifting everything up by min (recall that the smallest value is $$0$$) so that it has the image we want.

Question:
variables for array lengths:

In the textbook section 7.1, it states:

However to my understanding (and through testing) neither int or const int works in array length declaration. Am I misinterpreting this statement?
Answer:
I believe it's saying that the size of the array can be stored in an integer variable, for example, int size = 10; or const int size = 10;

It is saying that the length should be stored in an integer, that way it can be passed to functions. For example, if you have int arr[] = {1, 2, 3}, then you would want to store the size of the array in a variable like int or int const = 3. Or you could also do #define 

In the C language, you can't use a variable to declare the size of an array: you have to use a literal value. That is, a statement like int t=1; int tab[t]; is invalid, but int tab[10]; is acceptable. If you are curious as to why, it's because arrays need to have a known compile-time size in C (i.e. a literal), but a variable, even a const, is stored somewhere in memory, which is not usable for fixed size allocation.

Question:
Star pyramid help:

Whenever I make my conditions >= it wont fill the rest of my inner pyramid. Instead it will go crazy.

int main(void) {
  int lines=6;
  printf("Input number of lines: ");
  scanf("%d", &lines);

  // rows
  for (int row = 1; row <= lines; row++) {
    for(int col = 1; col<=(2*lines)-1;col++){
      if(col == lines||(col+row)==(lines+1)||(col-row)== lines -1){
        printf("*");

      } else {
        printf(" ");
      }
    }
    printf("\n");

  }

  return 0;
}
This is when it goes crazy.
Answer:
To clarify on the discussion below, your bounds are (col+row)==(lines+1) (lower bound?) and (col-row)== lines -1 (upper bound?) part of the condition. You also have col == lines .

I would write it as print star if ( col==lines±(row-1) ) so that you have col as a clear "independent variable" and clear bounds - the minus of the plus-minus is and lower bound, and the positive is the upper bound. 

You can combine all three of the above conditions into an inclusive range like so: print star if ( col >= lines - (row-1) && col <= lines + (row-1) ). This way you also don't have to include the condition col == lines because it's already in range.

If you try with inequalities using the condition above, it doesn't work as intended: 

 

though the inverted triangle is interesting

Question: Question on pointers: I'm still confused why pointers are necessary to allow a variable to be altered in a different function and also allow it to retain its value in the main function. What is going on in memory to allow a variable changed in another function to retain that change in the main function?
Answer:
Like the name, pointers literally “point” to memory addresses (the value a pointer stores is a memory address). When you pass a pointer/address into a function, you are telling the program where that variable lives in memory. That’s why you can alter it, since you are altering it at its source. When you pass by value (no pointer), the compiler creates a copy of that variable storing the same value in a different memory location. That is why you cannot edit variables in functions that have only been passed by value, you are not actually editing the variable from the caller function.  Like the name, pointers literally “point” to memory addresses (the value a pointer stores is a memory address). When you pass a pointer/address into a function, you are telling the program where that variable lives in memory. That’s why you can alter it, since you are altering it at its source. When you pass by value (no pointer), the function does not know where the value is, nor does it care since it only cares about the raw value  Like the name, pointers literally “point” to memory addresses (the value a pointer stores is a memory address). When you pass a pointer into a function, you are telling the program where that variable lives in memory. That’s why you can alter it, since you are altering it at its source. When you pass by value (no pointer), the function does not know where the value is, nor does it care since it only cares about the raw value  Like the name, pointers literally “point” to memory addresses. When you pass a pointer into a function, you are telling the program where that variable lives in memory. That’s why you can alter it, since you are altering it at its source. When you pass by value (no pointer), the function does not know where the value is, nor does it care since it only cares about the raw value 

Assume you have a variable X stored in memory address MEM1. When you pass X to a function, a new copy of X is created in MEM2 and this is what's passed to the function. Any changes made to X within the function are applied to MEM2, not MEM1. That's why when you return from the function, the value in MEM1 remains unchanged.

Now, assume you have a pointer P which stores the address MEM1 (MEM1 stores the value of X). P itself must be stored in an address, say MEM_P1. When P is passed to a function, a new copy of that pointer is created in MEM_P2 (this new copy still stores MEM1) and is passed to the function. Within the function, you can dereference the pointer (access the value in the memory address which is stored in the pointer) and make changes to it. This means that any change is done to the value stored in MEM1, which is the same original memory address storing the value of X. So, when you return from that function, the changes done to the variable stored in MEM1 are retained.

Question:
2019 Midterm Question 11 Inquiry:

Hello,

Can someone explain the logic behind this block of code (for the solution to q11, 2019 exam). I understand that you are now setting all negative values in the array to 0, but what does it mean if "index i was over-written" and shrink the array?
Answer:
When they shifted the later values of the array forward, it overwrites the value at index i. Looking at the loop just above the screenshot in the question, you can see it starts at int j = i;, and the loop moves each value following the one at i forward by one place. We must then decrement i to recheck whether or not the value immediately following the removed negative is also negative, since it would be skipped otherwise. 

Then array[size - 1] = 0 takes the final value in the array and makes it zero. This is equivalent to moving the negative to the back and deleting it, since we moved all the values behind the negative forward. If we did not do this, then the value at the end of the array at the start of the loop would remain there. 

Note that we aren't really "deleting" or "shrinking" anything. Like I said above, the "delete" is really just "make the last number 0 since we moved all other values forward" and "shrink" is really just "don't touch any of the 0s we've already placed" 

When they shifted the later values of the array forward, it overwrites the value at index i. We must then decrement i to recheck whether or not the value immediately following the removed negative is also negative, since it would be skipped otherwise. 

Then array[size - 1] = 0 takes the final value in the array and makes it zero. This is equivalent to moving the negative to the back and deleting it, since we moved all the values behind the negative forward. If we did not do this, then the value at the end of the array at the start of the loop would remain there.

When you subtract two pointers of the same type, the result is the difference between their addresses divided by the size of the data type. In this case, q = &x[2] = 24 (address of the third element of x) and x also points to its first element (&x[0] = 16). (The addresses 24 and 16 are arbitrary).

Question:
Modulo/RNG Question.: For random number generation, from my understanding, we do: (rand() % A) + B. To output intergers on: [B,A]

From what I can tell,  rand() % A will output numbers on [0, A-1] 
Why? I’ve been trying to rationalize it to myself mathematically, but was not successful yet.
Answer:
(I'll assume you know modular arithmetic for the following answer)

We consider only non-negative integers ($$\mathbb{Z}_{\ge 0}$$) since rand() only produces outputs in this set. The modulo operator is equivalent to computing a number's residue. For example, 3 % 5 in C is equivalent to $$(3\!\!\mod5)$$. When working mod $$n$$, there are exactly $$n$$ residue classes and hence $$n$$ unique (when taking the least residue set) residues. These form a set $$\left\{0,1,\ldots,n-1\right\}$$.

There is a slight error in your formula, it should be (rand() % (A-B+1)) + B) for the interval $$[B,A]$$. Adding $$B$$ "shifts" the numbers so that $$0$$ maps to $$B$$; $$1$$ maps to $$B+1$$ and so on. Moreover since the greatest possible residue is now $$A-B$$ this mapping will make the largest possible value $$A$$.

Question:
2020 Q4 Variables scope and redeclaring variables in loop:

Hi!

For the last part in 2020 Q4, I kind of understand why it gives 3 as final answer:

The outer variable i is declared at the very beginning and the statement "int = 1" in the for loop is kind of like using a new variable instead of i to complete the loop. So the outer i remains unchanged and the program prints 3 as output.

My questions are:

1. How does this code exactly work?

2. Is it legal to use the same variable name in the loop, since i has already been declared outside the loop and the variable name i has already been used. If we redefining i when initializing the loop, why won't it cause an error as the code shown below?

Thank you!
Answer:
I could be wrong here so feel free to edit but your understanding for why the program prints 3 is correct. As for the second question, the answer is yes, but only because the for loop begins a new scope 
<md>The for loop in itself has a scope of it's own. If you declare a variable inside it with the same name as another variable outside the loop, it is acceptable. This is what we referred to as "overlapping scope." 

However, if in the same scope you decide to declare a variable with the same name as you are doing in lines 3 and 4 of your screenshot, that is clearly a mistake. This is because you are in the same scope, and you are creating two variables with the same name.

This was clearly explained in lecture 15 at in 28:50 here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qXoR3H6kUEg</md>

Question:
Question 5 2022 Midterm:

I am confused as to how *fifth is being assigned 30? If the pointer to fifth is declared as data + first + 1, and first is equivalent to 1 at this point, and data without an array specifier is 10, wouldn't *fifth be equal to 12? Everything else checks out for me and I seem to have everything else right except for my value for *fifth. If someone could explain why *fifth is 30 I would appreciate it.

Thank you
Answer: fifth is assigned data + first + 1. data is an array of integers and first + 1 = 2, thus adding 2 to data is the same as offsetting it’s pointer by 2 x sizeof(int) = 8 bytes. This makes it point to index 2 of the array, or data[2] which equals 30. Fifth is assigned data + first + 1. Data is an array and first and 1 are integers, thus adding 2 to data is the same as offsetting it’s pointer by 2 x sizeof(int) = 8 bytes. Question: Midterm 2018 Q11: I don't understand what this problem is even asking me.
Answer:
First declare an array of 1000 integers that are randomly generated between 0 and 255 inclusive. This array must have repeated instances of certain numbers, and if rand() is "good", this distribution should be somewhat even, that is, each number "randomly" appears at around the same frequency. The problem is asking you to find the number of instances that a certain number appears in the 1000 integer array. 

For example, simplifying to an array of 10 values ranging randomly from 0 to 3, the array might look something like:

int arr[] = {1, 3, 0, 2, 3, 1, 0, 2, 1, 1}; 

The idea is to then create an array of length 4 (number of elements in the random range), whos ith index corresponds to the number of times i appears in the random array. So, that array would look like

int hist[] = {2, 4, 2, 2}; 

Since the 0th entry of hist corresponds to the number of times 0 appears in arr, and so on.

Question:
Midterm 2019 - Question 4:

First question, on line 7 why isn't it (age<=0) but instead   (*age<=0). 

Secondly, why is it requesting(&age) on line 13, if on line 3 the function is expecting a pointer, shouldn't the input on line 13 be (*age)
Answer:
The requestAge() function has an integer pointer has a parameter, so to access the value of the age variable, it needs to dereference it (using *age).

To get the address of a variable, you use the ampersand symbol. In this case, to pass a pointer to age to requestAge(), you do &age.

Question:
Memory Question.: What are the main regions of a computer’s memory that we care about in this course? 
Also, how do they behave as we run a program?
Answer:
I think we will learn this when we get to dynamic memory allocation, but I believe the main parts are the application memory and specifically the stack and heap.

The stack holds local variables and is of fixed size. Each time a new function is called, it along with what it contains in its local scope is placed on the stack. Since the stack is finite, it is possible to run out of space on it through too many function calls or large chunks of memory being allocated, thus we can use the heap which is dynamic (but still finite) and acts sort of like a memory pool. We can allocate and deallocate memory on the heap using malloc and free, and we store pointers to addresses of the heap on the stack. This lets us communicate between the fixed memory we have access to on the stack, and the pool of memory available in the heap. 

Hope this helps! And once again I think this is all talked about in the coming lectures

One thing to note is that stack is finite and heap is finite as well. Everything is restricted by the memory that the machine has.

Question:
2023 Midterm, would like some clarification on this::

In the solution, they stated for the second printf statement, *a = -5 and *b = 12. I personally ended up with *a = 17 and *b = 17. 

Here is my thought process after the first if-statement: 

*a = -5, *b = 7, and c = 3
a = b; //a now points to address of b

Question:
Boolean expressions:

Hi!

If I have the following code: bool x = (A || B && C); 

Is this equal to ((A || B) && C) or (A || (B && C))?

Thank you
Answer:
I believe <kbd>&&</kbd> has a higher precedence than <kbd>||</kbd>, so <kbd>B && C</kbd> is evaluated first. This means that it would be equivalent to <kbd>(A || (B && C))</kbd>.
I believe && has a higher precedence than ||, so B && C is evaluated first. This means that it would be equivalent to (A || (B && C)). 
<md>&& has higher precedence, but you are not expected to memorize this in life or for the exam. I would ask you to alway be extra cautious and put brackets around what you want to be evaluated first.</md>

Question:
Midterm 2019 Question 12:

Hi, can someone explain the logic of the inner loop of midterm 2019 question 12? I am not sure to understand how to get the pattern to calculate row #7 of Pascal's triangle.
Answer:
So there are two key variables that move together that allow us to compute the nth row, those being saveElement and oneToLeft.

We start oneToLeft at 0 which makes sense since the first entry of any row is going to be 1 (pArray[0] + oneToLeft = 1 + 0 = 1). Then for every subsequent element (call it i), pArray[i] is is updated to pArray[i] + pArray[i - 1], however pArray[i - 1] is not the element we can use in this case, since it was changed in the previous iteration. To compensate for this, we need to maintain the value of pArray[i - 1] before it is updated on the prior iteration. We maintain this value by updating oneToLeft to saveElement, and saveElement is the value of pArray[i - 1] before it is updated. 

So there are two key variables that move together that allow us to compute the nth row, those being saveElement and oneToLeft.

To compensate for this, we need to maintain the value of pArray[i - 1] before it is updated on the prior iteration. We maintain this value by updating oneToLeft to saveElement, and saveElement is the value of pArray[i - 1] before it is updated.

Question: function: when can a function change the value of variables which is defined outside the function and under what condition the functions cant change?
Answer:
If it is passed by pointer/address, it can be changed, if it is passed by value, it cannot
If it is passed by pointer/address, it can be changed, if it is passed by value, it cannot
In fact a function can never change the value of the parameter that is passed into the function from the caller scope. What you can do is to pass a pointer and now you can change the content that stores in that address.

small correction to student answer:

break does not cause unexpected behaviour if used more than once. It always does what it’s suppose to do… break out of the current loop. 
It’s not like accessing illegal memory which causes unexpected behaviour. 

The reason break is not liked is if you have numerous amount of break statements throughout your loop, it leads to multiple exit points within a loop which can be confusing. This trend is usually found for beginner coding courses (spamming break and continue whenever they can)

Having a couple here and there as “pre checks” is not bad practice and seen throughout industry.

Question:

  • (36 / 100) * 10 = 0 * 10 = 0.

So if number = 36, tenDigit = 3 - 0 = 3.

2020 Midterm Q7 Question:

Hi, I am confused by the solution for the question itself. How does the k value track the bit it is on? How does the while loop know when to stop? Won't this function just continuously go on forever since k starts off as 1 and is only multiplied by 2? I am quite confused by the working of the code, and would appreciate if someone could just break it down step by step for me.

Thank you!
Answer:
The idea of the program is that multiplication by two moves all the bits one place to the left (towards the more significant digits), for example $$(1)_{10}=(01)_{2}$$ and $$(2)_{10}=(10)_{2}$$.

The loop eventually ends because the maximum number of digits in a number is finite on a computer, and the most significant digit signifies the sign of the number. Specifically, when the most significant digit is set to 1, the number is negative. See the following example where there are only four bits in an integer:

$$(0001)_2=1_{10}$$, multiplying by two gives $$(0010)_2=2_{10}$$, again gives $$(0100)_2=4_{10}$$, and a 4th time gives $$(1000)_2<0_{10}$$.

By counting the number of multiplications required to create a negative number, we can thus determine the number of bits in an integer.

Question:
Void function return for midterm:

For int and double and bool and other function types, I know what we have to use return to indicate what value to return. However, for a void function, I know we can write return; and it would be fine but not writing return is also fine as it'll automatically return by itself. However, from what i know, not including return is the more "technically right" way, but would we lose marks for writing return; in a void function? It is just a habit I have from working with functions, and technically it wouldn't affect the code in any way, but I just wanted to make sure it would be fine and we would not lose marks.

Thank you
Answer:
After compilation, every function has (at least) one return instruction, even those declared void, so I would argue its not any less correct to include a return statement. For example, a swap function will compile (x86, Windows) to something similar to the following :

// forme void(int*,int*)
échangerEntiers: 
	mov eax, [rcx]
	mov r8d, [rdx]
	mov [rdx], eax
	mov [rcx], r8d
	ret

You might also want to break out of the function early (invalid input), you can use an return before the end of the function for this :

void afficherMaximum(int* tab, int longueur) {
	if (longueur <= 0) return;
	// un boucle se trouve ici ...
}

After compilation, every function has (at least) one return instruction, even those declared void, so I would argue its not any less correct to include a return statement. For example, a swap function will compile (x86, Windows) to something similar to the following : 

// forme void(int*,int*)
échangerEntiers: 
	mov eax, [rcx]
	mov r8d, [rdx]
	mov [rdx], eax
	mov [rcx], r8d
	ret

You might also want to break out of the function early (invalid input), you can use an return before the end of the function for this :

void afficherMaximum(int* tab, int longueur) {
	if (longueur <= 0) return;
	// un boucle se trouve ici ...
}

The student's anwer is way more involved. You will learn more about this in ECE243. For now, let's stick to the introduction level.

If a function has a void return type. Use return for early exit. You don't have to include a return in a void function. The function automatically returns at the end.

if a function has a void return type. Use return for early exit. You don't have to include a return in a void function.

Answer:
Note that q points to the address of the 6th element in arr.

The line p = q + 1 is essentially saying, p = q + 1 * sizeof(int), which is just the next location in memory. This means that p = &arr[6].

The same logic is used for p = q - 2: p = q - 2 * sizeof(int), which is two memory addresses back. This means that p = &arr[3].

Question: Using printf("%0.2lf", double): Does using "%0.2lf" truncate the double or round it?
Answer:
There is rounding that takes place when this format specifier is supplied to printf [1].

It is important to note that floating point operations use “round to nearest” (as defined by IEEE754 standard) in libc by default [2]. E.g. both 123.455 and 123.465 will be rounded to 123.46 if you use the format specifier “%.2lf”.
[1] https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/Floating_002dPoint-Conversions.html
[2] https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/Rounding.html

Midterm 2020 Q3: How do you know if something is an error or a warning?
Answer:
An error means that it cannot compile (ex. violation of syntax or language rules), a warning will still create the executable but will warn you of possible errors that may be raised at runtime. In the case of your example, x = *useCount is illegal since you can't dereference an int type variable, however int *q = &y is somewhat legal but just a type mismatch
An error means that it cannot compile (ex. violation of syntax or language rules), a warning will still create the executable but will warn you of possible errors that may be raised at runtime. In the case of your example, x = *useCount is illegal since you can't dereference an int type variable, however int *q = &y is somewhat legal but just a type mismatch

Errors violate syntax or language rules but warnings do not. In the case of your example, x = *useCount is illegal since you can't dereference an int type variable, however int *q = &y is somewhat legal but just a type mismatch

In the case of your example, x = *useCount is illegal since you can't dereference an int type variable, however int *q = &y is somewhat legal but just a type mismatch
<md>You are not required to differentiate between an error and a warning. You are only required to know if a statement is valid (correct) or invalid (incorrect).</md>

Question:
Midterm 2023 Question 8:

Could I get an explanation on this solution? I don't understand how the while loop is set up, as well as how the if statements work.
Answer:
The condition while(1) always evaluates to true (since any nonzero number is equivalent to true. This means that the loop will continuously run, unless there's a statement that breaks out of it in its body.

The first if statement checks if you're at the end of array A (since a negative value, specifically -1, indicates you are at the end). If this is true, it then checks if you're at the end of array B. If both arrays are at the end, then the dot product is defined and you can return the sum. However, if you're not at the end of array B, arrB[i] < 0 evaluates to false, which means that B still has more elements, so their sizes don't match, so you return -1.

If the first check passes (if there's still more elements in array A), you still need to check if there are still more positive integers in array B, hence the second if statement. If the second if statement evaluates to false, then it means that array A still has more elements, but you're at the end of array B. This then means that the array sizes don't match, so you return -1.

If this second check also passes, then you would know that there's still more elements to process in arrays A and B, so you can continue computing the dot product.

This loop continues until both arrays end at the same time or if there's a size mismatch.

MIDTERM 2019 q3:

Can someone explain why statement 2 is legal? Also, a brief explanation on 1 and 3 would be helpful to confirm I have the right thought process!
Answer:
Statement 1 is illegal because p is a pointer and i is an integer, and you can't assign an integer value to a pointer (type mismatch).

Statement 2 is legal since you are dereferencing p, and that allows us to modify/access the value at its memory address. In this case, the value of i is assigned to the memory location that p points to.

Statement 3 is illegal since you are dereferencing q, but assigning it the memory address of i, and you can't assign an address to an integer (another type mismatch).

Statement 3 is illegal since you are dereferencing q, but assigning it the memory address of i, and you can't assign an address to an integer (another type mismatch).

Question:
character array:

Hi, the following is my 2d array and what it prints out. How do I fix it? For example, south-east turns into south-eastsouth. So it's taking from the next array element.
Answer:
fixed^ i had to make the 10 into 11 instead. anyone know why?

Note that strings are null-terminated, meaning that the last character in the string is the null character (\0). When you're printing strings using the format specifier %s, it will print from the first element of your string to the first null character (exclusive).

However, when your column length is exactly as long as the longest word, there's not enough space for the null character (for those words that are as long). So when you're printing, it will continue to move onto the next element until it encounters a null character. That's why the column length should be the length of the longest string plus one.

Note that strings are null-terminated, meaning that the last character in the string is the null character (\0). When you're printing strings using the format specifier %s, it will print from the first element of your string to the first null character.

However, when your column length is exactly as long as the longest word, there's not enough space for the null character (for those words that are as long). So when you're printing, it will continue to move onto the next element until it encounters a null character. That's why the column length should be the length of the longest string plus one.

Question:
Lab 6 ECF Problems:

Hello 

When I try to run my lab6 codes on ECF i get the following error:

"program output contains non ascii characters"

I've tried the solution posted by the TA by manipulating the settings but it didn't work.

I've also encountered the issue where the lab6 output is different on ECF than my personal computer. The same code gets the same results as the test cases when run on my personal computer but are just completely wrong when run on ECF. 

I'm so confused why is this the case.
Answer:
When you get non-ASCII <kbd>printf</kbd> output, it's often an indicator that you're accessing uninitialized and/or unreserved memory with an argument variable. For this program, I recommend you check that all the array indices are correct and that they are in bounds, since that is the most likely uninitialized space.
When you get non-ASCII <kbd>printf</kbd> output, it's often an indicator that you're accessing uninitialized and/or unreserved memory with an argument variable. I recommend you check that all the array indices are correct and that they are in bounds.

Question:
lab 6 read word function:

I'm struggling with steps one and two of the readWord function; if you want to store the number of character in a point to wordSize, would you store the input using " "%d" ,wordSize" (ex. no * or & used). Then to dynamically allocate an array using wordsize, would you used &wordSize to get the integer? I keep getting this error in my code:
Answer:
1. Since wordSize is a pointer variable it already has the correct type for scanf -- we want to store an integer so we need a pointer to an integer for the argument.


2. No, the code *(wordSize) is correct for accessing the stored value (it's a pointer to an integer so you need to use the dereference operator to retrieve the value) -- the warning here occurs because malloc takes an unsigned integer (i.e. positive), but there's a possibility that *(wordSize) stores a negative value (the input will always be a positive number but the int type doesn't guarantee this so the compiler can't be sure).

Question:
Lab 7 - Declaring a 26 x 26 Array?:

In the header for Lab 7, the board 2d array is defined as having 26 columns, rather than n columns (which we cannot change).

Also, in the instructions for declaring the board, it says not to "declare variable-length arrays":

Does this mean that we should be declaring a 26 x 26 array regardless of what the user inputs, then printing only the first n columns/rows of said array?

If so, what is the advantage of defining the array in this way, since we're already assuming that the user will give a valid input (ie. the user won't give a # too large to be stored in memory)? Wouldn't we be wasting memory to define a 26 x 26 array when a 4 x 4 array would have been sufficient?
Answer: This is most likely for our convenience. Of course, dynamic allocation of the board would be more efficient for memory but in this case, since the board can only be a maximum of 26 by 26 it is sufficient to allocate the maximum amount of memory.

Question:
2D array size and declaration:

Hi, I was doing lab 7, and I declared the 2D array board like this:

From my understanding, this 2D array would only have one row with 26 columns, with the first column filled with "\0" and the rest 25 columns automatically filled with "\0" as well. 
However, I found I can still access "row two" using the expression board[1][0], as seen in the debugger:

I want to check if my understanding is correct:

This is because the 2D array board is essentially a pointer, and the expression board[][] can access addresses that are not part of the 2D array board. 

Furthermore, I continued with my declaration of "char board[][26] = {'\0'};", and my "printBoard" function works. 

That means I changed the value in the address board[1][0], which is technically not part of the 2D array board, to 'U'. (If the board size is 4*4, then initially, row 2 column 1 would be 'U'.)

I wonder if this declaration is a bad coding style, as I am changing a value in a technically undeclared address and using that undeclared address in future codes. 

I also wonder if the values stored in these undeclared addresses may change midway during the program runs. 

Additionally, if I declare board like "char board[26][26] = {'\0'};", can I imagine the computer build a "fence" around all addresses of the 26*26 2D array in the main stack, where the values stored in these addresses can only be changed by the program. Whereas if I declare board like "char board[][26] = {'\0'};", I am going into "public space" when I am accessing board[1][0], and the addresses in the "public space" can be changed by other operations other than your program, which is unsafe. 

Just want to check if my understanding on this is accurate, thank you!
Answer:
<md>`char board [][26] = {'\0'};` is setting the intention that it is a 1 row with 26 columns 2D array. 

Accessing board[1][1] would be going outside the bounds of the array, and is indeed not correct. The debugger may allow it if the memory space is not used for something else in your computer. If you do so, your program has an undefined behavior. We can't predict what will happen. But this is indeed incorrect. It is not bad coding style. It is incorrect. If it works on your computer, it won't work on ECF. 

You must declare the array as `char board[26][26];` Your program can only access this 2D array, and no other process on your computer should be able to access your array.</md>

Question:
Lab 8 Part 2 Leaderboard:

Hi,

Although I am hugely inexperienced in programming, I love the leaderboard feature. 

I was just wondering how the teaching team would ensure that students do not simply search online for the 'smartest' algorithms and copy? Are there checks for ingenuity? It would be a shame for my small program to be mauled by the most competitive algorithm out there which wasn't made by a student. 

Sorry if my concern is misplaced; again, this is my first programming course. 

Thanks
Answer:
The rules for the leaderboard say that a move should take, at max, 1 second to compute by an algorithm on the ecf server or your lose on a time out (0 Points).

Most of these 'smart algorithms' online use some sort of tree search algorithm (MCTS for example). These algorithms are 'smart' because they can create a tree of possible future positions and search through them to some depth to find the overall most advantageous branch and choose moves as such.

This means even though for example, I'd like to use a tree search to look ahead, the depth at which these trees can look into will be pretty limited because of the time constraint as tree searches indeed have strong performance but not usually very fast calculation times.

The rules for the leaderboard say that a move should take, at max, 1 second to compute by an algorithm on the ecf server or your lose on a time out (0 Points).

Most of these 'smart algorithms' online use some sort of tree search algorithm (MCTS for example). These algorithms are 'smart' because they can create a tree of possible future positions and search through them to some depth to find the overall most advantageous branch and choose moves as such.

This means even though for example, I'd like to use a search tree to look ahead, the depth at which these trees can look into will be pretty limited because of the time constraint as tree searches indeed have strong performance but not usually very fast calculation times.

You can indeed search online for some "smart algorithms".

Very famous ones are alpha beta pruning with a decision tree. 

You can try implementing this and set a time limit for < 1 second.

This is allowed.

When I took aps105 3 years ago, a lot of tips and tricks were actually to either 

1. Search up strategies on how to win reversi

2. Read academic papers on how to win reversi (parameter tuning with alpha beta pruning and what not).

You'll get in big trouble if you simply copy the "source code" from online. Academic integrity software detectors blah blah will catch that as well as more than likely another student will have done the same. However, you can search up what alpha beta pruning is or a "smart algorithm" for reversi and try and code this up. Or you can do number 1 and code up these strategies. Or you can try coming up with your own heuristics and seeing if it works

Question:
About lab8:

when I try to run my code, why my code always jumps over this scanf. I mean when I run the code, my code doesn’t ask me to scanf the letter.
Answer:
It could be because there is a newline character in the input buffer after your first scanf() statement. When the second scanf() is run, it is storing the newline character instead of inputting 'B' or 'W'.

To fix this, you should put a space before the format specifier to ignore any whitespaces (newline characters, spaces. etc...): scanf(" %c", ...);

It could be because there is a newline character in the input buffer after your first scanf() statement. When the second scanf() is run, it is storing the newline character instead of inputting 'B' or 'W'.

To fix this, you should put a space before the format specifier to ignore any whitespaces (newline characters, spaces. etc...): scanf(" %c", ...);

Question:
Lab8 Part2 Question:

Hi, I have two questions regarding this part:

1. Do we have to consider the case where our colour has no available moves? What should the row and col be in that case (e.g. NULL?)

2. Also, should our makeMove() function detect if the game has ended? For example, if the game ends but this function still returns a row & col , does that mean we lose the game?

Thanks!
Answer:
No, you do not have to consider either case. This is because your function will only be called when there is a valid move to be played. As for when the game ends, when your algorithm is tested, it will be placed into a fully functional game in which when the game is over will be accounted for.

quick answer: No, the structure of the game when testing your function will account for both 1 and 2.

Question:
Warning of Different Qualifiers:

Good morning,

@897 does not solve this issue

If I use (char board[][26]) in the function prototype, everything works out fine. However, if I use (const char board[][26]) and input regular board into the function, the following "different qualifier" error appears.

I think it is because I am trying to input a regular board into a constant. However, I am not allowed to modify the function prototype. What should I do? Please advice.

Thank you!
Answer: @897 is right, this is only a warning and will not affect functionality (assuming you do not change the board). The only way to silence this warning is to pass a constant board to makeMove( ). What you can do is make a copy of the current board state in main and have that copy be a constant board. Then when you pass it as a parameter there will be no warning. I recommend just leaving the warning as is. @897 is right, this is only a warning and will not affect functionality (assuming you do not change the board). The only way to silence this warning is to pass a constant board to makeMove( ). What you can do is make a copy of the current board state in main and have that copy be a constant board. Then when you pass it as a parameter there will be no warning. I recommend just leaving the warning as is.

Lab8part2 MakeMove confusion:

Hello,

Therefore, the whole code for lab8part2 includes the main function and the makeMove function. If I want to refer to another function in my main function, like for example, a function called computerMove, computerMove must be located in the makeMove function (per the lab 8 instructions). Therefore, do I have to call makeMove first and then call computerMove in the makeMove function.
