Answer:
makeMove saves the best move. So it saves it inside *row and *col. That's why they are pointers. It chooses the position for your computer to move.

You need your other functions inside makeMove to presumably help you find out what the best move is

Question: MakeMove Function Clarification: Once we implement the makeMove function, should the makeMove function also flip the tiles? Or only set the row and col pointers to the best position for our ai?

Question:
Segfault After Player Has No Valid Move - Lab8Part2:

I am unsure if anyone can help me on this or if anyone has had similar problems, however I thought it was worth asking. 

When I run my program everything runs smoothly except for whenever the human player has no valid move and the computer has to repeat a move. Then for some reason it just runs into a segfault. This does not occur whenever the computer runs out of moves and the human player has to input it again. 

I am unsure as to why this is the case but I am wondering if anyone else has run into similar issues. I have been attempting to debug this for hours and am unsure where to proceed from here. Any debugging tips or solutions would be great.
Answer:
You turned on debugger which is good and you can see the value of each variable at the moment of the crash. Likely out of bound access.
Are you using any common variables between the player move and when you actually execute moves onto the board? Your issue could arise if you are adding values to an index counter which you reset to 0 in your human player move, but are not setting to 0 when you execute moves. If you are continually adding without setting back to 0 and you try to access an array at this unexpectedly large index, it may cause a segfault error.

Question: string functions: What does strncmp and strcmp return specfically. Does it return the exact index it found both letters. Example: lets say s1=banana and s2 = lama. will it return 1 because the index is the same at 1
Answer:
The strncmp(s1, s2, n) and strcmp(s1, s2) functions compares two strings. It returns three different types of integers:

  • Returns an integer less than 0 when s1 comes before s2 in the dictionary.
  • Returns 0 when s1 and s2 are the same.
  • Returns an integer greater than 0 when s1 comes after s2 in the dictionary.

In your example, strcmp(s1, s2) will return an integer that is less than 0, since "banana" comes before "lama" in the dictionary. This section of the textbook describes it in detail: https://learningc.org/chapters/chapter10-strings/string-functions#comparing-strings

The strncmp and strcmp functions compares two strings. It returns three different types of integers:

  • Returns an integer less than 0 when s1 comes before s2 in the dictionary.
  • Returns 0 when s1 and s2 are the same.
  • Returns an integer greater than 0 when s1 comes after s2 in the dictionary.

In your example, strcmp(s1, s2) will return an integer that is less than 0, since "banana" comes before "lama" in the dictionary. This section of the textbook describes it in detail: https://learningc.org/chapters/chapter10-strings/string-functions#comparing-strings

The strncmp and strcmp functions compares two strings. It returns three different types of integers:

  • Returns an integer less than 0 when s1 comes before s2 in the dictionary.
  • Returns 0 when s1 and s2 are the same.
  • Returns an integer greater than 0 when s1 comes after s2 in the dictionary.

In your example, strcmp(s1, s2) will return an integer that is less than 0, since "banana" comes before "lama" in the dictionary.

Question:
Lab8 Part 2 failing all test while winning against both faster and fastest algorithm on ecf:

Hello, I am having trouble passing my testcases for part 2.  I tried my code on the ecf computer and I checked that I won against smarter and smartest but when i submit it, I get all test failed in part 2.

Thank you for your help
Answer:
I had this same issue and if it there was a runtime error, the submission would let you know. I fixed mine by making sure that I was actually modifying the pointers 'row' and 'col' correctly by subtracting each of the values they were pointing to by 1 to ensure that the dereferenced number reflects the actual indices of the 2D board array. (Ex. if you wanted to make the move 'ab', then you want to ensure *row = 0 and *col = 1).

Hope this helps!

Question:
Compiling Code Part 2:
have followed the steps on the Quercus lab posting about the directory lab8part2 and the settings.json. However, I currently do not have a liblab8part2.a file because when I remote connect on ECF, I cannot find a way to add one. Can you please clarify what it means by "If you use Windows, please use ECF" (in the Quercus post) and "If you are on Windows, it won't work as we didn't provide a library for Windows. Please ECF for this part. You can compile, run and debug your code then." (in the Piazza FAQ).
Also, when it says to "compile and run" my code, does that mean clicking the gear in VSCode and then the arrow, or by entering the "gcc reversi.c -L. -llab8part2 -std=c99 -o lab8part2" command then "./lab8part2". This is because as of right now, I have only been able to see if my program works by clicking the submit command and seeing it fails for all 4 part2 test cases.

To give some more context:
  • When I run the gcc command, it is in my lab8part2 directory, so my settings.json is set to "\"${workspaceFolder}/liblab8part2.a\""
  • When I run the gcc command, I either get "cannot find -llab8part2" or "In function `main': reversi.c:(.text+0x4a4): undefined reference to `findSmarterMove' reversi.c:(.text+0x694): undefined reference to `findSmarterMove' collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status" errors
Answer:
you should download the .a file, the liblab8part2.h file and place in the same directory as where your lab8part2 code is.
Copy over the .h and .a file onto the remote ecf. This can be done with an scp command (many things online on this) or just by dragging the file from your local computer to your ecf vscode window. 

You’re not suppose to create a .a file on ecf.

Also, you can use the command or the gears button. It says alternatively use the command so it’s equivalent

Question:
Received email from ECF:

Is this caused by my submission of lab8 or some other issue, if I already submitted lab8 should I worry about this?
Answer: No need to worry. Please make sure you have no infinite loops and you're closing your remote connection to ECF when you are done.

Question:
Bot Works When Testing Manually But Fails When Ran on ECF:

Hello, whenever I test my bot using 

gcc reversi.c -L. -llab8part2 -std=c99 -o lab8part2

./lab8part2

My bot manages to beat the "smarter" AI for both W and B.  

However, whenever I run the test cases on the ECF it fails to pass any test cases. Could this be due to time complications? Or is there anything else I forgot to consider. 

I followed the instructions by only adding the makeMove() function and what not as-well.
Answer: It's indeed an issue in your code. Did you test manually on ECF by putting in inputs by hand? If not, please do and use the debugger there. There is a chance that you're having an uninitialized variable or you're accessing elements outside the bounds of an array.
